  78 -class distance_to_pointset(object): 

  79      """First and second maximum and/or minimum distances of a point q 
  80      to a set of points, returning a dictionary keyed by 'min' and 
  81      'max' to dictionaries keyed by integers 1 and 2 (respectively). 
  82      The values of this dictionary are dictionaries of 
  83        'd' -> distance 
  84        'pos' -> index into pts 
  85   
  86      To restrict the search to a lower-dimensional subspace, specify a sub-set 
  87      of the variables in q. Defaults to Euclidean distance (normord=2),otherwise 
  88      specify metric-defining norm order. 
  89   
  90      To speed up the search, use n > 1 to create n segments of the pointset, 
  91      from which representative points will first be assessed, before the search 
  92      narrows to a particular segment. Be sure to use a large enough n given 
  93      the variation in each segment (which will otherwise cause spurious results 
  94      for certain test points). Default n=30. 
  95      [NB This option currently only returns the first max/min distances] 
  96   
  97      The radius option provides an opportunity to use information from 
  98      a previous call. This works for minimum distances only, and forces 
  99      the same segment to be searched, provided that the new point is 
 100      within the radius of the previous point (using 2-norm unless a 2D 
 101      Point is specified). CURRENTLY, THIS DOES NOT WORK WELL. KEEP IT 
 102      SWITCHED OFF USING (default) radius=0. 
 103   
 104      If gen is not None, it should contain a generator for use with isochron-related 
 105      events, for more accurate computations. The remaining arguments are associated 
 106      with this usage. 
 107      """

 139              else:

 141                  # space the segment representatives in middle of segments 
 142                  self.seg_start_ixs = [step*i for i in range(n)] 
 143                  rep_pts = [pts[step*i+half_step] for i in range(n)] 
 144                  # treat any remainder segment specially 
 145                  # if remainder is too small then combine it with previous 
 146                  # segment (choose m>=6 fairly arbitrarily) 
 147                  self.segments = [] 
 148                  base_ix = 0 
 149                  for i in range(n): 
 150                      self.segments.append(pts[base_ix:base_ix+step]) 
 151                      base_ix += step 
 152                  if m >= 6: 
 153                      half_step_last = int(floor(m/2.)) 
 154                      self.segments.append(pts[base_ix:]) 
 155                      rep_pts.append(pts[n*half_step+half_step_last]) 
 156                      self.seg_start_ixs.append(step*n) 
 157                  else: 
 158                      # replace last segment with all the rest of the points, 
 159                      # making it longer 
 160                      self.segments[-1] = pts[base_ix-step:] 
 161                      # leave rep_pts[-1] alone 
 162                  self.rep_pts = pointsToPointset(rep_pts) 
 163          # record of [last segment identified for 1st and 2nd MINIMUM distance, 
 164          #                                                           last point] 
 165          # max distances are not currently recorded 
 166          self.clear_history()

 434 -def find_nullclines(gen, xname, yname, subdomain=None, fps=None, n=10, 
 435                      t=0, eps=None, crop_tol_pc=0.01, jac=None, max_step=0, 
 436                      max_num_points=1000, only_var=None, seed_points=None, 
 437                      strict_domains=True): 

 438      """Find nullclines of a two-dimensional sub-system of the given 
 439      Generator object gen, specified by xname and yname. 
 440   
 441      Inputs: 
 442   
 443      gen is a Generator object 
 444      xname, yname are state variable names of gen 
 445   
 446      Optional inputs: 
 447   
 448      Restriction of x and y to sub-domains can be made using the subdomain argument. 
 449      subdomain may contain pairs (min, max) or singleton values that fix those state 
 450      variables and restrict the fixed point search to the remaining sub-system on the 
 451      given ranges. (default to domains given in generator). There must be exactly 
 452      two ranges remaining (for xname, yname) to give a two-dimensional nullcline 
 453      problem, unless only_var option has been used (see below). 
 454   
 455      n = initial number of meshpoints for fsolve. Do not set this large if using 
 456        PyCont, e.g. use n=3. Default is 10. 
 457   
 458      Set t value for non-autonomous systems (default 0). Support for Jacobians 
 459        with non-autonomous systems is not yet provided. 
 460   
 461      jac is a Jacobian function that accepts keyword arguments including t for 
 462        time (even if Jacobian is time-independent). 
 463   
 464      max_step (dictionary) tells PyCont the largest step size to use for each 
 465        variable. Integer 0 (default) switches off PyCont use. Use None 
 466        to tell PyCont to use default max step size (5e-1). 
 467   
 468      fps can be a list of points previously calculated to be fixed points, 
 469        which this function will use as additional starting points for 
 470        computation. 
 471   
 472      eps sets the accuracy to which the nullclines are calculated. Default is 
 473        approximately 1e-8. 
 474   
 475      crop_tol_pc is the percentage (default 1%) for tolerance outside the specified 
 476        domain for keeping points in nullclines -- final points will be cropped with 
 477        this tolerance. 
 478   
 479      only_var (variable name) requests that only the nullcline for that variable 
 480        will be computed. The variable name must correspond to xname or yname. 
 481   
 482      seed_points can be used if an approximate position on either nullcline is already 
 483        known, especially useful if there are no fixed points provided. One or more 
 484        seed points should be given as a list of dictionaries or Points with keys or 
 485        coordinates xname and yname. These should be collected as values of the 
 486        seed_points dictionary, whose keys (xname and/or yname) indicate which points 
 487        belong to which nullclines. 
 488   
 489      strict_domains (boolean, default True) ensures all computed nullcline points are 
 490        cropped to lie within the given sub-domains. 
 491   
 492   
 493      Output: 
 494          (x_null, y_null) arrays of (x,y) pairs. Fixed points will be included if 
 495          they are provided (they are expected to be calculated to high enough 
 496          accuracy to smoothly fit with the nullcline sample points). 
 497   
 498      Note that the points returned are not guaranteed to be in any particular 
 499      order when PyCont is not used. 
 500      """ 
 501      vardict = filteredDict(copy.copy(gen.initialconditions), gen.funcspec.vars) 
 502      # get state variable domains if subdomain dictionary not given 
 503      if subdomain is None: 
 504          subdomain = filteredDict(gen.xdomain, gen.funcspec.vars) 
 505      else: 
 506          subdomain = gen._FScompatibleNames(subdomain) 
 507          assert remain(subdomain.keys(),gen.funcspec.vars) == [] and \ 
 508                 remain(gen.funcspec.vars,subdomain.keys()) == [] 
 509      if only_var is None: 
 510          do_vars = [xname, yname] 
 511      else: 
 512          assert only_var in [xname, yname], "only_var must be one of xname or yname" 
 513          do_vars = [only_var] 
 514      fixed_vars = {} 
 515      try: 
 516          x_dom = subdomain[xname] 
 517      except: 
 518          x_dom = gen.xdomain[xname] 
 519      if not (isfinite(x_dom[0]) and isfinite(x_dom[1])): 
 520          raise PyDSTool_ExistError("Must specify finite range for %s"%xname) 
 521      try: 
 522          y_dom = subdomain[yname] 
 523      except: 
 524          y_dom = gen.xdomain[yname] 
 525      if not (isfinite(y_dom[0]) and isfinite(y_dom[1])): 
 526          raise PyDSTool_ExistError("Must specify finite range for %s"%yname) 
 527      for varname, dom in subdomain.iteritems(): 
 528          if isinstance(dom, (tuple,list)): 
 529              if not (isfinite(dom[0]) and isfinite(dom[1])): 
 530                  raise RuntimeError("Must specify a finite range for %s" % varname) 
 531          else: 
 532              fixed_vars[varname] = dom 
 533      if fixed_vars != {}: 
 534          vardict.update(filteredDict(gen._FScompatibleNames(dict(fixed_vars)), 
 535                          remain(gen.funcspec.vars, [xname, yname]))) 
 536      var_ix_map = invertMap(gen.funcspec.vars) 
 537      max_step = gen._FScompatibleNames(max_step) 
 538      xname_orig = gen._FScompatibleNamesInv(xname) 
 539      yname_orig = gen._FScompatibleNamesInv(yname) 
 540      xname = gen._FScompatibleNames(xname) 
 541      yname = gen._FScompatibleNames(yname) 
 542      x_ix = var_ix_map[xname] 
 543      y_ix = var_ix_map[yname] 
 544      pp_vars = [xname, yname] 
 545      pp_vars.sort() 
 546      pp_var_ix_map = invertMap(pp_vars) 
 547      def xdot_x(x, y, t): 
 548          vardict[yname] = y 
 549          vardict[xname] = x 
 550          return gen.Rhs(t,vardict,gen.pars)[x_ix] 

 551      def ydot_y(y, x, t): 
 552          vardict[yname] = y 
 553          vardict[xname] = x 
 554          return gen.Rhs(t,vardict,gen.pars)[y_ix] 
 555      def xdot_y(x, y, t): 
 556          vardict[yname] = y 
 557          vardict[xname] = x 
 558          return gen.Rhs(t,vardict,gen.pars)[y_ix] 
 559      def ydot_x(y, x, t): 
 560          vardict[yname] = y 
 561          vardict[xname] = x 
 562          return gen.Rhs(t,vardict,gen.pars)[x_ix] 
 563      if gen.haveJacobian(): 
 564          # user-supplied Jacobian if present 
 565          def xfprime_x(x, y, t): 
 566              vardict[xname] = x 
 567              vardict[yname] = y 
 568              return gen.Jacobian(t, vardict, gen.pars)[x_ix] 
 569          def xfprime_y(x, y, t): 
 570              vardict[xname] = x 
 571              vardict[yname] = y 
 572              return gen.Jacobian(t, vardict, gen.pars)[y_ix] 
 573          def yfprime_x(y, x, t): 
 574              vardict[xname] = x 
 575              vardict[yname] = y 
 576              return gen.Jacobian(t, vardict, gen.pars)[x_ix] 
 577          def yfprime_y(y, x, t): 
 578              vardict[xname] = x 
 579              vardict[yname] = y 
 580              return gen.Jacobian(t, vardict, gen.pars)[y_ix] 
 581      elif jac is not None: 
 582          # assumes **args-compatible signature! 
 583          xix = pp_var_ix_map[xname] 
 584          yix = pp_var_ix_map[yname] 
 585          # x will be first argument to these 
 586          xfprime_x = lambda x, y, t: array(jac(**{'t': t, xname: x, 
 587                                        yname: y})[xix]) 
 588          xfprime_y = lambda x, y, t: array(jac(**{'t': t, xname: x, 
 589                                        yname: y})[yix]) 
 590          # y will be first argument to these 
 591          yfprime_x = lambda y, x, t: array(jac(**{'t': t, xname: x, 
 592                                        yname: y})[xix]) 
 593          yfprime_y = lambda y, x, t: array(jac(**{'t': t, xname: x, 
 594                                        yname: y})[yix]) 
 595      else: 
 596          xfprime_x = None 
 597          xfprime_y = None 
 598          yfprime_x = None 
 599          yfprime_y = None 
 600      if eps is None: 
 601          eps = 1.49012e-8 
 602      x_range = list(linspace(x_dom[0],x_dom[1],n)) 
 603      y_range = list(linspace(y_dom[0],y_dom[1],n)) 
 604      x_null_pts = [] 
 605      y_null_pts = [] 
 606   
 607      if fps is not None: 
 608          fps_FS = [gen._FScompatibleNames(fp) for fp in fps] 
 609          add_pts_x = [fp[xname] for fp in fps_FS]

 611      else:

 613          add_pts_y = [] 
 614      seed_pts_x = []

 632

 634      y_range = seed_pts_y + add_pts_y + y_range

 638      rout = redirc.Redirector(redirc.STDOUT) 
 639      rout.start()

 642              try:

 646                                 xddot=yfprime_y,xtol=eps/10.)) for y in y_range])

 648                  rout.stop() 
 649              except:

 651                  raise 
 652      if xname in do_vars: 
 653          for y0 in y_range:

 661              except:

 665      xwidth = abs(x_dom[1]-x_dom[0]) 
 666      ywidth = abs(y_dom[1]-y_dom[0]) 
 667      xinterval=Interval('xdom', float, [x_dom[0]-crop_tol_pc*xwidth, 
 668                                         x_dom[1]+crop_tol_pc*xwidth]) 
 669      yinterval=Interval('ydom', float, [y_dom[0]-crop_tol_pc*ywidth, 
 670                                         y_dom[1]+crop_tol_pc*ywidth])

 672                                  xinterval, yinterval), eps*10)

 674                                  xinterval, yinterval), eps*10)

 676      # max_step = 0 means do not use PyCont to improve accuracy 
 677      if max_step != 0: 
 678          add_fp_pts = array([add_pts_x, add_pts_y]).T 
 679          if not isinstance(max_step, dict): 
 680              max_step = {xname: max_step, yname: max_step} 
 681          # use PyCont to improve accuracy 
 682          # PyCont will order the points so can draw lines 
 683          loop_step = 5 
 684          # current limitation! 
 685          # pycont won't find disconnected branches of nullclines so we have to seed 
 686          # with multiple starting points 
 687          # - also, the following assumes more than one point was already added to 
 688          # these lists 
 689          # Y 
 690          if yname in do_vars:

 696                  y_init = y_null[0,1] 
 697              elif fps is not None and len(fps) > 0:

 703              else:

 705                  y_init = (y_dom[0]+y_dom[1])/2.

 707                  x_init = x_dom[0] 
 708              elif x_init > x_dom[1]: 
 709                  x_init = x_dom[1] 
 710              if y_init < y_dom[0]: 
 711                  y_init = y_dom[0] 
 712              elif y_init > y_dom[1]: 
 713                  y_init = y_dom[1] 
 714              sysargs_y = args(name='nulls_y', pars={xname: x_init},

 723              sysargs_y.pars.update(gen.pars) 
 724              sysargs_y.pars.update(filteredDict(vardict, [xname, yname], neg=True)) 
 725              sysargs_y.pars['time'] = t

 727              P = ContClass(sys_y)

 730              PCargs.MinStepSize = 1e-8 
 731              PCargs.VarTol = PCargs.FuncTol = eps 
 732              PCargs.TestTol = 1e-8 
 733              if max_step is None: 
 734                  PCargs.MaxStepSize = 5e-1 
 735                  PCargs.StepSize = 1e-6

 738                  PCargs.StepSize = max_step[xname]*0.5

 741              # check every loop_step points until go out of bounds 
 742              done = False 
 743              num_points = 0 
 744              while not done: 
 745                  try: 
 746                      P['null_curve_y'].forward() 
 747                  except PyDSTool_ExistError: 
 748                      print 'null_curve_y failed in forward direction' 
 749                      raise 
 750                  else: 
 751                      num_points += loop_step 
 752                      # stop if have tried going forwards more than twice and solution is 
 753                      # still not within domain, or if num_points exceeds max_num_points 
 754                      done = (num_points > 5*loop_step and not \ 
 755                              check_bounds(array([P['null_curve_y'].new_sol_segment[xname], 
 756                                                    P['null_curve_y'].new_sol_segment[yname]]).T, 
 757                                              xinterval, yinterval)) \ 
 758                            or num_points > max_num_points 
 759              done = False 
 760              num_points = 0 
 761              while not done: 
 762                  try: 
 763                      P['null_curve_y'].backward() 
 764                  except PyDSTool_ExistError: 
 765                      print 'null_curve_y failed in backward direction' 
 766                      raise 
 767                  else: 
 768                      num_points += loop_step 
 769                      # stop if have tried going backwards more than twice and solution is 
 770                      # still not within domain, or if num_points exceeds max_num_points 
 771                      done = (num_points > 5*loop_step and not \ 
 772                              check_bounds(array([P['null_curve_y'].new_sol_segment[xname], 
 773                                                    P['null_curve_y'].new_sol_segment[yname]]).T, 
 774                                              xinterval, yinterval)) \ 
 775                           or num_points > max_num_points 
 776              # can get repetition of some points 
 777              if strict_domains:

 788              x_vals_unique, indices = unique(x_vals, return_index=True) 
 789              y_null = y_null[indices] 
 790              # add fixed points to nullcline, assuming sufficient accuracy 
 791              # also searchsorted assumes monotonicity in x values, i.e.

1292          y ranges over 0 to 1, x_relative_scale=100 is appropriate.

1816      """Bisection root-finding method.  Given a function returning +/- 1 
1817      and an interval with func(a) * func(b) < 0, find the root between a and b. 
1818

1842              b = p

2803 -def _filter_consecutive(indices, minimize_values=None): 

2804      """Return index array containing no consecutive values. 
2805      if minimize_values option is given, this sequence must contain positions for 
2806      all indices in the first argument, and will be used to choose which of any 
2807      consecutive indices to retain in the returned sequence. Otherwise, the first 
2808      index will be chosen arbitrarily. 
2809   
2810      E.g. to find the *last* index of every cluster instead of the default, use 
2811        minimize_values=range(max_index,0,-1) 
2812      """ 
2813      ## Find clusters 
2814      clusters = [map(operator.itemgetter(1), g) for k, g in \ 
2815                  itertools.groupby(enumerate(indices), lambda (i,x):i-x)] 
2816      ## Minimize on clusters 
2817      result = [] 
2818      for c in clusters: 
2819          if len(c) == 1: 
2820              result.append(c[0]) 
2821          else: 
2822              if minimize_values is None: 
2823                  result.append( c[0] ) 
2824              else: 
2825                  mvals = np.array(minimize_values) 
2826                  representative = np.argmin(np.array([mvals[c]])) 
2827                  result.append( c[representative] )
